Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Multi-Regional Scale Aircraft Observations of Methane and Carbon Dioxide Isotopic Fluxes in the Arctic
Award.AbstractNarration: This proposal directly addresses the release of carbon dioxide and methane from terrestrial melt zones and ocean systems that result from the loss of the Arctic Ocean ice cover. Airborne measurements of the fluxes of isotopologues of methane and carbon dioxide will be conducted using a new spectrometer system developed at Harvard under an NSF MRI initiative. This instrument has sufficient precision and accuracy to distinguish between thermogenic and biogenic sources of carbon in the Arctic, as well as measuring N2O and water vapor, as well as other tracers. NOAA?s Atmospheric Turbulence and Division Division (ATDD) bring their expertise in field deployments of airborne flux systems as well as a Best Air Turbulence (BAT) probe to the field mission. The broader impacts of the proposed activity emerge from the unique measurements and monitoring strategy of this project to develop a foundation for a national carbon monitoring network, which will be a key component of any program or international agreement to limit carbon emissions. The project will fill a technological void and deliver a system that is versatile by design, allowing for myriad future applications that are centered on specific carbon-related issues, such as sequestration and forest chemistry, as well as assessing the overall country-by-country inventory of carbon.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The quantitative determination of methane and carbon dioxide emissions to the atmosphere globally from the most important source and sink regions constitutes a first order imperative in the union of energy, climate, and public policy for this country. To address this objective, we employed a strategy using the new Flux Observations of Carbon from Airborne Laboratory (FOCAL) system. The FOCAL platform provides spatially resolved, high accuracy and high precision emission measurements of methane and carbon dioxide, and their stable isotopes, emitted from the Arctic as the permafrost melts each summer. The imperative for the field study using the revolutionary FOCAL platform stems from the observation of rapid and unexpected changes in the Arctic climate in combination with the risks associated with accelerating the forcing of climate by methane and carbon dioxide release from permafrost and clathrates. Changes in the climate system and the rapidity with which they can occur was dramatically demonstrated by the decrease in Arctic sea ice at the end of the summer of 2007, and is a pattern that has continued through the 2014 melt season as shown in Figure 1. This sudden decrease in sea ice was not predicted and is not well characterized in models.  Closely related to this problem is the issue of warming permafrost and deep ocean systems, which release methane and carbon dioxide, potentially adding substantial climate forcing. Understanding the magnitude of methane emissions, as the length of the melting season and the depth to which the grounds melts increase, is the focus of this research. 

In order to make flux measurements from an airplane and also to distinguish which types of lakes and plants were emitting the most methane, the airplane needed to fly very close to the surface (<30 meters). Figure 2 shows the airplane flying near a portable tower setup to make similar measurements, but in only one specific location.

Our results show a very heterogenous landscape when it comes to methane emissions. Figure 3 shows one flight over a 50x50 sq-km grid. The underlying tundra is a mixture of different sized lakes and different plant communities. Our current efforts are to correlate the high emissions measurements with specific geomorphic and biological features. This demonstrates one of the reasons regional aircraft measurements are so important. As there are thousands of lakes and very few roads,  measurements by towers or traps in just a few locations cannot capture the geographic structure of the emissions. This leads to large uncertainties in total regional methane emission estimates. By measuring over large regions FOCAL can reduce uncertainty in the amount of methane coming from the Arctic.
